headline: Unity at start of Biden's State of the Union speech gives way to familiar domestic battles
author: Ronald J. Hansen
sentences:
Supreme Court won't let Arizona voters weigh in on tax cut Brnovich takes election manual fight with Hobbs to court Karrin Taylor Robson drops fundraising tactic after questions AZ House Speaker Rusty Bowers wins award for courage
Rep. Paul Gosar, R-Ariz., said the speech signaled Biden's administration is failing and has resorted to political gimmicks.

"I welcome President Biden’s support for our policies boosting American manufacturing of semiconductors, ensuring Arizona veterans — including those exposed to harmful burn pits — receive the care they’ve earned, and lowering health care costs for Arizona seniors," Sinema said in a written statement.

"Congress should be focused on efforts like these to fix our supply chains and drive down costs, including by directing Medicare to negotiate drug prices, boosting our trucking workforce, and taking more immediate steps like getting rid of the federal gas tax for the rest of the year."

Sen. Kyrsten Sinema, D-Ariz., praised Biden for noting the expansion of semiconductor manufacturing, specifically from Intel, a company with a major Arizona presence, but also called for slimmed-down governmental spending, a talking point popular with many Republicans.

"I was also pleased to hear the president’s plan of action to address comprehensive immigration, pay down the deficit, and address supply-chain issues and lower costs for families by investing in American goods, manufacturing, and jobs," he said in a statement.

Biden's hourlong State of the Union address to Congress fused get-tough rhetoric on Russia with an array of more-familiar — and politically charged — initiatives, ranging from tackling prescription drug pricing to reinvigorating American manufacturing.

"In the Senate I negotiated and passed a plan to boost microchip manufacturing in Arizona and across the country, and I was glad to see the President place a priority on getting our legislation across the finish line," he said in a statement.

Rep. Raúl Grijalva, D-Ariz., who chairs the House Natural Resources Committee, said in a tweet that "we are at a precipice with fossil fuels" and welcomed Biden's call for more investment in alternative energy sources, from solar to wind.

President Joe Biden's full-throated support for Ukraine Tuesday night seemed to briefly unite members of Congress, including Arizona's divided delegation, but as he turned to domestic policy matters, the familiar partisan lines reemerged.

Rep. Andy Biggs, R-Ariz., tweeted acidly throughout the speech, suggesting Biden walked into the House chamber not understanding where he was to writing, "YOU LIE," ahead of a series of attacks on his management of the southern border.

"Whether it was an economy in turmoil, soaring COVID-19 cases, an inauguration in the aftermath of the Jan. 6 insurrection, or the need to rebuild diplomatic alliances abroad, this administration has met the moment in every instance.
... And as the united Western and NATO response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine has demonstrated, President Biden has very much restored the United States’ leadership on the world stage."
“Gasoline, grocery, and energy prices are soaring, crime has risen through the roof, the southern border is wide open, fentanyl is killing our kids, and war has broken out in Ukraine.
"I’m grateful that (Biden) again voiced his support for our bill to allow Medicare to negotiate for lower drug prices — now the Senate needs to act," Stanton said in a statement.
"Instead of offering solutions to move our country forward, the President spent over an hour trying to tell the American people that his failures are really accomplishments.
The past year has been marked by foreign policy failures, record levels of crime, an open border with fentanyl pouring through, and historic levels of inflation."
After Biden mentioned the government will send masks and COVID-19 testing equipment to homes, Biggs responded, "Free high-quality Chinese masks coming your way."

President Biden is going to have to do more than offer empty rhetoric.”

Rep. Tom O'Halleran, D-Ariz., praised the president for leadership on Ukraine and passage of the infrastructure bill last year before turning to other issues.
I call on the administration to ensure government spending is targeted and thoughtful — because a lean and efficient government helps avoid prices hikes."
Arizona's Democrats largely offered support for Biden's agenda, while its Republican members were quick to focus on what they viewed as nonstarter issues.
It was a list of things he knows he cannot pass, meant to do nothing more than to provide false hope and divide Americans," he said in a tweet.
Rep. Ann Kirkpatrick, D-Ariz., who is retiring after this year, didn't immediately issue a statement about the president's speech.
Rep. Greg Stanton, D-Ariz., welcomed Biden's support for allowing the government to bargain for lower prescription drug prices.
"However, I was disappointed not to hear a mention of the importance and role of rural America in the president’s remarks."
Sen. Mark Kelly, D-Ariz., also noted the manufacturing issue, while calling for inflation-fighting moves to aid Americans.
"Excited to hear (Biden) will be cracking down on corporations that are driving prices up during the pandemic," he wrote.
Rep. Debbie Lesko, R-Ariz., focused largely on kitchen-table issues as a reality check on the nation's present health.
"Regardless of what President Biden said this evening, it doesn’t change the fact that we are a country in crisis.
Rep. Ruben Gallego, D-Ariz., cast the speech as marking a major shift from the state of the union a year ago.
"Coming into office, the Biden-Harris administration faced historic challenges," he said in a statement.
"Arizonans want to get back to normal, but continue to be hurt by rising prices and empty store shelves.
He also favors a response to what many view as profit-driven inflation during the pandemic.
"I am a cosponsor of bills to stop price gouging, lower costs and help working people."
Rep. David Schweikert, R-Ariz., compared Biden's speech to a "fiction novel."
It was a complete distortion of reality," he said in a statement afterward.
"Tonight was the last gasp of a dying and desperate Administration.
